user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of digest_get_size:
```c
_MHD_static_inline unsigned int
digest_get_size (struct DigestAlgorithm *da)
{
  mhd_assert (! da->uninitialised);
  mhd_assert (da->algo_selected);
#ifdef MHD_MD5_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_MD5 == da->algo)
    return MD5_DIGEST_SIZE;
#endif /* MHD_MD5_SUPPORT */
#ifdef MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA256 == da->algo)
    return SHA256_DIGEST_SIZE;
#endif /* MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT */
#ifdef MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA512_256 == da->algo)
    return SHA512_256_DIGEST_SIZE;
#endif /* MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT */
  mhd_assert (0); /* May not happen */
  return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
  mhd_assert (0); /* May not happen */
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The assertion itself is not inherently unreachable: it will be executed if da->algo does not match any of the compiled-in algorithm cases (e.g. when none of the preceding if conditions are true). Therefore, as written, Rule 2.1 is not necessarily violated. However, a violation can occur in a specific build/configuration: if the project configuration and types guarantee that one of the earlier return statements always executes (for example, all algorithm support macros are enabled and the DigestAlgorithm enum contains only those values so da->algo must match one of them), then the mhd_assert(0) and the following return 0 would be provably unreachable and would violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1.
